video.title: Learn Data Science Tutorial - Full Course for Beginners
video.description:
Learn Data Science is this full tutorial course for absolute beginners. Data science is considered the "sexiest job of the 21st century." You'll learn the important elements of data science. You'll be introduced to the principles, practices, and tools that make data science the powerful medium for critical insight in business and research. You'll have a solid foundation for future learning and applications in your work. With data science, you can do what you want to do, and do it better. This course covers the foundations of data science, data sourcing, coding, mathematics, and statistics.

💻 Course created by Barton Poulson from datalab.cc.
🔗 Check out the datalab.cc YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/datalabcc
🔗 Watch more free data science courses at http://datalab.cc/

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ Part 1: Data Science: An Introduction: Foundations of Data Science
  - Welcome (1.1)
  - Demand for Data Science (2.1)
  - The Data Science Venn Diagram (2.2)
  - The Data Science Pathway (2.3)
  - Roles in Data Science (2.4)
  - Teams in Data Science (2.5)
  - Big Data (3.1)
  - Coding (3.2)
  - Statistics (3.3)
  - Business Intelligence (3.4)
  - Do No Harm (4.1)
  - Methods Overview (5.1)
  - Sourcing Overview (5.2)
  - Coding Overview (5.3)
  - Math Overview (5.4)
  - Statistics Overview (5.5)
  - Machine Learning Overview (5.6)
  - Interpretability (6.1)
  - Actionable Insights (6.2)
  - Presentation Graphics (6.3)
  - Reproducible Research (6.4)
  - Next Steps (7.1)
    
⌨️ Part 2: Data Sourcing: Foundations of Data Science (1:39:46)
  - Welcome (1.1) 
  - Metrics (2.1)
  - Accuracy (2.2)
  - Social Context of Measurement (2.3)
  - Existing Data (3.1)
  - APIs (3.2)
  - Scraping (3.3)
  - New Data (4.1)
  - Interviews (4.2)
  - Surveys (4.3)
  - Card Sorting (4.4)
  - Lab Experiments (4.5)
  - A/B Testing (4.6)
  - Next Steps (5.1)

⌨️ Part 3: Coding (2:32:42)
  - Welcome (1.1)
  - Spreadsheets (2.1)
  - Tableau Public (2.2)
  - SPSS (2.3)
  - JASP (2.4)
  - Other Software (2.5)
  - HTML (3.1)
  - XML (3.2)
  - JSON (3.3)
  - R (4.1)
  - Python (4.2)
  - SQL (4.3)
  - C, C++, & Java (4.4)
  - Bash (4.5)
  - Regex (5.1)
  - Next Steps (6.1)
         
⌨️ Part 4: Mathematics (4:01:09)
  - Welcome (1.1)
  - Elementary Algebra (2.1)
  - Linear Algebra (2.2)
  - Systems of Linear Equations (2.3)
  - Calculus (2.4)
  - Calculus & Optimization (2.5)
  - Big O (3.1)
  - Probability (3.2)
          
⌨️ Part 5: Statistics (4:44:03)
  - Welcome (1.1)
  - Exploration Overview (2.1)
  - Exploratory Graphics (2.2)
  - Exploratory Statistics (2.3)
  - Descriptive Statistics (2.4)
  - Inferential Statistics (3.1)
  - Hypothesis Testing (3.2)
  - Estimation (3.3)
  - Estimators (4.1)
  - Measures of Fit (4.2)
  - Feature Selection (4.3)
  - Problems in Modeling (4.4)
  - Model Validation (4.5)
  - DIY (4.6)
  - Next Step (5.1)

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://www.freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.author: Lemurai
topLevelComment.text: I got into data science through nursing, I was an ICU nurse looking for a hiatus in the job, that’s how I  broke into the field, via the hospital system but I do have a secondary degree in bio chemistry which helped significantly on the quantitative side of things. Bio statistics is a staple in an biochemistry program and if anyone else’s prof’s were like mine, you’d swear they were teaching engineering in the amount of quantitative topics I was put through. I was however very weak on the he business end of things and had to be paired with someone for about a solid 8 months. But it was an awesome transition to another career.

The video doesn't have a goal specific . It has tried to be an Jack of All trade but will make watchers to master of nothing. For beginners who want to know an outline to study Data Science , I recommend to watch something else . You will pretty much waste ur time on this video for unnecessary stuffs to beginners. topLevelComment.author: Drew Crawford
topLevelComment.text: First off, thank you for this course. This was a huge eye opener for me about all that goes into data science. They say you don’t know what you don’t know and I realize now that I don’t know much at all.  I was really enjoying using SQL and Python to pull data down and “play” with it but after watching this entire video I think I need to find something else to do. This course was so incredibly dense with theories, concepts and terminology that learning this just feels impossible to me. Maybe if I had taken collage level algebra, statistics and calculus this may have been a great refresher but without that prior knowledge, this just seems unattainable. I thought that data annalist roles are less intense than this but now I'm just not sure about anything. Regardless of my ability to understand this, the video is amazing and incredibly well done. I’m sure it will help a lot of people getting into data science.

replies.author: datalabcc
replies.text: Drew, this is Bart Poulson, who created the video. It sounds to me like you're doing exactly the right thing. The math background is nice but far from essential. Curiosity about data, along with some facility with tools like SQL and Python, all of which you have, are an excellent foundation.

topLevelComment.author: JorgeG121
topLevelComment.text: I have been doing data analytics in business (marketing, pricing and strategy) since before the term was invented (early 90s) and I have never written a word of code in my career (ok I tell a lie, I have used packaged bits of code for R but never learned it). So why is 'data science' and big data so focused on coding, SQL etc. IMHO, there is massive confusion out there:  Data science and data analytics are just two different things, they are related but different. Think about it as Formula 1 car and F1 driver:  The data scientists are the engineers that build the car, the data analytics is the driver that uses the car (the data) to win races.  Yet, in the 'big data' world, people expect one single person to have engineering skills (data management, database creation) AND piloting skills (analytics) whereas in the F1 context that would be absurd: An engineer who helps build the F1 car and a F1 pilot have completely different skills and roles. They absolutely need each other but they are completely different.

replies.author: datalabcc
replies.text: This is Bart Poulson, who created the video. What it really means is that there is always slippage, always a mismatch between the answer you want, the question that is actually asked, the way that data is gathered, the way the algorithm processes the data, and so on. Nothing line up perfectly. It's fine if it's random error at each point, as those differences tend to cancel each other out, even if they introduce a fair amount of noise into the system. What's problematic is when the mismatches tend to go in the same direction and reinforce each other. There are many good examples of this in social systems, but it also can happen in technical systems. The point is not to conduct "political reviews," but the opposite: to make sure there is a better match at each step of the process in a transparent and justifiable manner, acknowledging limitations as the come up.

replies.author: datalabcc
replies.text: This is Bart Poulson, who created the video. Of course you're right that many people with minimal experience don't make one excellent person. But the point that I was trying to make was not to accumulate mediocrity but to aggregate range of experience. The skills required to clean data quickly and effectively are not the same as the skills required to develop a useful machine learning model, and neither is the same as the skills required to put that model into production. Obviously, you would want excellent people at each stage. It's just that you may need different people to do all of them well.

replies.author: Iggy
replies.text:
I know this is a late comment, and I'm not sure how far along in your learning. That being said, my answer to you is this: fortunately, the programming fundamentals between Data Science and Software Engineering are interchangeable. However, it depends on how you want to use those programming languages.


If you prefer building infrastructure and pipelines, full-stack websites, and data environments, software engineering is more for you. In contrast, if you enjoy cleaning and dissecting data, and optimizing company workflow with information being processed across several statistical measures, data science is more for you.


Both are algorithm and math heavy, the deeper you go. From what I've seen/read (as I'm not someone there yet) at the higher levels, data scientists and data engineers choose which they want to prioritize. Both fields are highly attractive, highly sought, and highly necessary.

replies.text: When I was in grad school to get my PhD in social psychology, the common usage was that "sex" referred to being biologically male or female (defined by genetics or some other standard) and that "gender" referred to the social characteristics of masculinity and femininity. topLevelComment.author: Thomas Rowe
topLevelComment.text:
Data science is an approach. It doesn't need to fit into some bucket. I don't like when you say your not doing data science because it doesn't fit in this bucket. This is like saying children aren't doing science and research because they haven't created a hypothesis or written a report. Considering sciences as meeting requirements is just like school that requires you to separate math, physics, and English into their own separate subjects. It is fine to teach the difference between the skills and I know that sometimes its important to see how they overlap as well. However, this isn't always practical and its actually more effective to have someone who has overlapping skills. Sometimes those skills are enough to even call that person a polymath. We shouldn't continue to teach things in isolation because that would create overspecialization. We are seeing overspecialization from people getting degrees from schools but unable to get good jobs with those skills. 

It would be more productive to just say that it is an approach. Use that approach to design experiments using those approaches. Such as when you are playing a game like chess and you develop skills against one player. You need to make sure your skills aren't overfit or underfit in the game of chess because when you play against another player if your skills overfit to your model you will be overconfident in your skills.

replies.author: datalabcc
replies.text: I couldn't agree more. I made the videos and I'm pretty sure I never said "you're not doing data science because it doesn't fit in this bucket." Is there a part of the video that suggested that?

replies.author: datalabcc
replies.text: I created the videos and I said that because I sincerely believe it: data science requires substantial creativity. The whole point of data science is to find meaning in data that resists that process. If it were easy and if it didn't require creativity, then it would be plug-and-play work for a technician, not work for a data scientist. It also requires creativity to find business cases and user value for the results of data science analyses. So I stand by my claim: data science is a creative field.

replies.author: datalabcc
replies.text:
It's true that education is important (I'm a professor and I have two masters and a PhD) but what's odd is exactly what that education needs to be, as there are still not many options for dedicated programs in data science (as opposed to, say, computer science or business administration). There's still room for quantitatively-oriented people from many fields.


And you're absolutely right that enormous progress is being made in machine-learning-as-a-service and that the work is becoming increasingly automated. But data science operates in a competitive environment: it's a question of whether you can get better insights faster than the other organizations. That often involves creating new algorithms, new applications, and bringing in new data. I believe that there will always be a need for people who can get insight from data and do something useful with it.


Bart

replies.author: datalabcc
replies.text:
I made the videos and it's correct that they were made in 2016. They've been on YouTube channel (https://youtube.com/datalabcc) and freeCodeCamp.org found them recently and asked to include them here. However, given that this is course is a conceptual introduction, the information is just as relevant now as it was then. If it were a technical tutorial, then that would be different, as the tools and methods have changed dramatically in the last few years. But for people who are just trying to figure out what is meant by "data science" and where to get started, I believe it's still very useful.
Bart

replies.author: datalabcc
replies.text: Wouldn't that be fabulous! However, it's going to take more than six hours of anything to get a job like that (as I'm sure you know). But there are still things in this course that are going to be helpful if you want to get a job at Google (or anywhere else) as a data science programmer: project planning, framing business questions, interpretation, communication, and so on. It's nearly impossible to create technical training in data science that will stay relevant for more than a few months but many of the "soft skills," which are very important to employers, stay relevant for years.

replies.author: datalabcc
replies.text: Nothing like it used to be. For example, the most recent version of "The Popularity of Data Science Software" at http://r4stats.com/articles/popularity/ shows SAS as having much lower demand, decreasing in academic research, and so on. I don't know a single newly-minted data scientist who uses it, although a number of people from academic fields will still use it. It's similar to how SPSS persists in academic fields like mine (I'm in psychology).
